e4: The current accounting practice, while potentially carrying legal risk, has served to maintain market stability. This is an attractive option. Introducing a new, unbiased policy will bring clarity and alignment with actual earnings, but the initial volatility may be higher until market adjustments set up in a similar fashion to recent years. The short-term costs are offset by the long-term benefits of market trust and compliance while avoiding potential lawsuits and negative public relations. This is an important aspect for the company's longevity.
e5: An ethical reporting policy should prioritize honesty and transparency while remaining responsible to stakeholders. It needs to be clear, concise, easily understood by all parties, and avoid misleading investors about financial projections or performance. Transparency regarding potential future risks, as well as full disclosure of any existing liabilities, are further elements that should be central to the reporting process.
e6: Yes, a follow-up with the management team is essential to understand how this change will be implemented and supported.  Questions about investor communication plans regarding potential market volatility in the short term would also aid in understanding their reasoning for implementing a new policy without any bias.
